entry.pr: ˈsō, especially before adjective or adv followed by “that” sə
entry.et: Middle English, from Old English swā; akin to Old High German sō so, Latin sic so, thus, si if, Greek hōs so, thus, Latin suus one's own suicide

def.dt: :in a manner or way indicated or suggested do you really think so often used as a substitute for a preceding clause are you ready? I think so I didn't like it and I told her so
:in the same manner or way :also worked hard and so did she
:thus 1 for so the Lord said Isa 18:4(Authorized Version)
:then subsequently and so home and to bed
:to an indicated or suggested extent or degree had never been so happy
:to a great extent or degree :very extremely loves her so
:to a definite but unspecified extent or degree can only do so much in a day
:most certainly :indeed you did so do it
:most decidedly :surely I so don't believe you
:therefore consequently the witness is biased and so unreliable

entry.pt: The intensive use of so (sense 2b) is widely condemned in college handbooks but is nonetheless standard why is American television so shallow? Anthony Lewis the cephalopod eye is an example of a remarkable evolutionary parallel because it is so like the eye of a vertebrate Sarah F. Robbins the kind of sterile over-ingenuity which afflicts so many academic efforts Times Literary Supplement. There is no stigma attached to its use in negative contexts and when qualified by a dependent clause not so long ago was so good in mathematics that he began to consider engineering Current Biography. The denotation in these uses is, of course, slightly different (see sense 2a). Another emphatic use of so (sense 2e) has developed more recently and occurs mostly in informal contexts.

def.dt: :with the result that the acoustics are good, so every note is clear
:in order that be quiet so he can sleep
:provided that
:for that reason :therefore don't want to go, so I won't

dt.un: used as an introductory particle so here we are often to belittle a point under discussion so what?
used interjectionally to indicate awareness of a discovery so, that's who did it or surprised dissent

def.dt: :in order to

entry.pt: Although occasionally condemned, use of so to introduce clauses of result (sense 1a) and purpose (sense 1b) is standard. In sense 1b so that is more common in formal contexts than so alone.

def.dt: :conforming with actual facts :true said things that were not so
:marked by a desired order his books are always just so

dt.un: used to replace a preceding adjective was witty by adult standards and of course doubly so by mine Sally Kempton

def.dt: :such as has been specified or suggested :the same if you have to file a claim, do so as soon as possible

dt.un: used in the phrase or so to indicate an estimate, approximation, or conjecture stayed a week or so cost $15 or so

def.dt: seller's option
strikeout
south; southern
:insofar as
:during and up to the end of the time that :while so long as you are here, I'm fine
:provided that you may go, so long as you return by dinnertime
